title: N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 20 § 151.2 - Who must file a New York State personal income tax return
content:
N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 20 § 151.2 - Who must file a New York State personal income tax return

State Regulations

Tax Law, §§ 651(a) and 658(a)
(a) Except as otherwise provided in this

Subchapter, a New York State personal income tax return must be made and filed
by or for: (1)
every resident individual: (i) required to file a Federal income tax
return for the taxable year; or
(ii)
having New York adjusted gross income
for the taxable year, determined under Part 112 of this Title, in excess of the
sum of such individual's New York personal exemptions, but not including an
individual, husband and wife, head of a household or surviving spouse who, pursuant to section
601 (a)(2)
of the Tax Law is
not required to pay an ordinary tax; or
(iii)
having any New York items of tax
preference in excess of the specific deduction determined under section
122.7
(a) of this Title; or
(iv)
subject to
the separate tax imposed by section
601
- D of the Tax Law, upon the termination
of a qualified higher education fund; or
(v) having received during the taxable year a
lump sum distribution, any portion of which is subject to the separate tax
imposed by section 601-C of the Tax Law; (2)
every resident estate or trust: (i) required to file a Federal income tax
return for the taxable year; or
(ii)
having any New York taxable income for
the taxable year determined under Part 118 of this Title; or
(iii)
having any New York items of tax
preference in excess of the specific deduction determined under section
122.7
(b) of this Title; or
(iv)
subject to
the separate tax imposed by section 601-D of the Tax Law, upon the termination
of a qualified higher education fund; or
(v) having received during the taxable year a
lump sum distribution, any portion of which is subject to the separate tax
imposed by section 601-C of the Tax Law; (3)
every nonresident individual (nonresident
partners of partnerships, including limited liability partnerships or limited
liability companies that are treated as partnerships for Federal tax purposes, nonresident members of professional athletic teams, nonresident shareholders of

New York S corporations, and nonresident members of groups or organizations
authorized by the commissioner to file group New York State nonresident
personal income tax returns for their members should also see sections
151.17, 151.18, 151.19
and
151.20, respectively of this Part, and also see section
151.21
of this Part): (i) having New York adjusted
gross income for the taxable year, determined under Part 132 of this Title, in
excess of the sum of such individual's New York personal exemptions, but not
including an individual, husband and wife, head of a household or surviving
spouse whose New York adjusted gross income for the taxable year, computed as
if a resident, meets the provisions of section
601 (a)(2)
of the Tax Law
and is not required to pay an ordinary tax. However, notwithstanding the
provisions of the preceding sentence, a New York State nonresident personal
income tax return must be filed for the year in which a net operating loss is
incurred by a nonresident individual who incurs a net operating loss for New

York State personal income tax purposes but does not incur a net operating loss
for Federal income tax purposes; or
(ii)
having any items of tax preference
derived from or connected with New York State sources in excess of the specific
deduction determined under section
141.2
(a) of this Title; or
(iii)
subject to
the separate tax imposed by section 601-D of the Tax Law, upon the termination
of a qualified higher education fund; or
(iv)
having received a lump sum distribution
during the taxable year, any portion of which is derived from or connected with

New York State sources and which is subject to the separate tax imposed by
section 601-C of the Tax Law; (4)
every nonresident estate or trust: (i) having items of income or gain derived
from or connected with New York State sources, determined in accordance with
the applicable rules of Part 132 of this Title as in the case of a nonresident
individual, in excess of such nonresident estate's or trust's New York personal
exemption. However, notwithstanding the provisions of the preceding sentence, a

New York State fiduciary income tax return is required to be filed for the year
in which a net operating loss is incurred by a nonresident estate or trust
which incurs a net operating loss for New York State personal income tax
purposes, but which does not incur a net operating loss for Federal income tax
purposes; or
(ii)
having any items
of tax preference derived from or connected with New York State sources in
excess of the specific deduction determined under section
141.2
(b) of this Title; or
(iii)
subject to
the separate tax imposed by section 601-D of the Tax Law, upon the termination
of a qualified higher education fund; or
(iv)
having received a lump sum distribution
during the taxable year, any portion of which is derived from or connected with

New York State sources and which is subject to the separate tax imposed by
section 601-C of the Tax Law. (b) A taxpayer who comes within any of the
requirements for filing a New York State personal income tax return (as
provided in paragraphs [a][1]-[4] of this section) must file a personal income
tax return even if such return, after deductions, exemptions and credits, shows
no income tax liability. (c) A
taxpayer is not excused from making a New York State personal income tax return
merely because he does not receive a copy of such return form from the Tax

Commission. Copies of the prescribed forms will, as far as possible, be
distributed to taxpayers by the Tax Commission, but a taxpayer who does not
receive these forms should make application therefor to the Tax Commission, or
at any district tax office, in ample time to have his New York State personal
income tax return prepared and filed on or before the due date. Notes
